objinfo.printdate: c. 1804-05The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the first one printed c. 1804-05. The second impression in this printing is *Nebuchadnezzar* in the Minneapolis Institute of Arts (Butlin 303).
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Acquired by Thomas Butts in 1805 from Blake; Thomas Butts, Jr., apparently by inheritance in 1845; Frederick J. Butts, apparently by inheritance in 1862; his widow, c. 1905, by inheritance; sold 1906 through Carfax and Co., London, to W. Graham Robertson; given 1939 by Robertson to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection).

objnote.p: The subject of "Nebuchadnezzar" is derived from the biblical Book of Daniel, 4:31-33. A "voice from heaven" tells the Babylonian monarch that he will "be with the beasts of the field." The prophecy is fulfilled immediately, and Nebuchadnezzar grows "hairs ... like eagles' feathers" and "nails like birds' claws." For Blake, this image probably represented the descent of a mighty ruler, and perhaps all of humanity, into a state of fallen nature.
The title, "Nebuchadnezzar," is inscribed in pencil below the design, almost certainly not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nebuchadnezzar, transformed into a nude, beast-like figure with claw-like nails and long, shaggy hair and beard, crawls towards the right but turns his head to face the viewer. His mouth is open and his eyes look down in an expression indicating a mixture of horror and shock. Feather-like fur covers part of his body and upper legs. He crawls along grassy ground in front of the trunks of two large trees that lean towards each other and form a cave-like space between them. Other vegetation appears upper left (pine branches?) and upper right (oak branches?).

component.illusobjdesc: Nebuchadnezzar, transformed into a muscular nude, beast-like figure with spiky claw-like nails on his hands and feet and long, shaggy hair and beard, crawls towards the right with his head turned to face the viewer. His long hair cascades over his neck. His hands are on the ground with his fingers together. His right arm is slightly before his left arm. Feather-like fur covers part of Nebuchadnezzar’s torso and continues to his knees. His right leg is extended behind his left leg. His right foot has its toes spread on tiptoe, perhaps digging into the ground. His facial expression is a mixture of despair, horror, and fear with his mouth open and his eyes wide and downcast.
The trunks of two large trees lean towards each other behind Nebuchadnezzar. They form a dark cave-like space between them, visible below Nebuchadnezzar's stomach.
In the upper left corner of the design a few branches of a (pine?) tree are discernible.
In the upper right corner of the design a few branches of an (oak?) tree are discernible. A few of its leaves appear in front of the tree trunk on the right.
The foreground is covered with grass, moss, lichens, or a mixture of all three. There is a dark shadow lower left.
The dark area on the left margin may be the sky (at night?).
